awd_titl_txt: EXCITON PHASE TRANSITION IN ATOMICALLY THIN 2D SEMICONDUCTORS
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical  Abstract: 
Optical excitations in semiconductors create electron and hole pairs. These quasiparticles are responsible for optoelectronic behavior of materials used in many device applications including, photovoltaics, light emitting diodes and light detectors. These electron and hole quasiparticles, similar to particles in ambient, can go through phase transitions from noninteracting gas to condensed liquid phase at high enough densities and low temperatures. The condensed quasiparticle state exhibits very different electronic properties compared to dilute phase. However so far the studies involving the electron-hole condensation are limited to very low temperatures and high laser excitation densities in limited group of material systems. This project focuses on study of these condensed electron-hole states in atomically thin semiconductors at high temperatures. The educational component of the research involves recruiting high school students specifically from underrepresented communities to the labs. 

Technical Abstract
Atomically thin 2D transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDC) provide a remarkable excitonic system with a large exciton binding energy, more than an order of magnitude larger than typical semiconductor materials. These materials can provide unprecedented opportunities for the studies of quantum many-body physics at elevated temperatures. It has been known that excitons at high enough densities condense into electron-hole plasma and then into a liquid. But in general this gas to liquid phase transition takes place at cryo-temperatures. Here the proposed work aims to study the phase transition of excitons in 2D TMDC materials into a state of electron-hole liquid (EHL) at room temperature and above. This exciton condensation is a quantum mechanical analogue of the classical gas condensation into a liquid droplet. This work will pursue a thorough understanding of the exciton condensation in 2D TMDC materials.

por.por_cntn:
In this project we studied electron-hole liquid phase transition in 2D TMDC materials. In semiconductors electronic excitations exists in their most simple form as electrons and holes. These are negative and positive charge carriers. These charges can form excitons through Coulomb interaction. Under critical condititions these excitons can condense in real space. This dense excitonic system at first can evolve into plasma, then form liquid. This liquid is very similar to gas to liquid formation in normal materials. The major difference is electron-hole liquid (EHL) is a liquid of quasiparticles in a semiconductor. 

EHL is a very high energy density state. It is metallic in nature, and its recombination kinetics, transport kinetics  are completely different compared to electrons in semiconductors. 

Because the binding energy of an individual carrier to a EHL droplet is too low, EHL conventionally be only formed at very low temperatures.

In this work, we observed EHL formation in 2D TMDC materials at room temperature. We characterized density of electrons and holes and measured the lifetime of this state. Our findings show that while normal excitons recombine in ps to ns lifetimes, EHL recombines in 100s of ns time scale.

We also found that strain plays an important role in EHL formation. We found that because of strain carriers accumulate in different bands in MoS2. We theoretically modeled the EHL PL emission lineshapes using the Fermi Liquid theory and found the density of carriers in K and Gamma valleys in the MoS2. These studies also helped us to develop unique experimental techniques. First we developed micro Raman experiments to measure the strain, temperature in the 2D materials with micron spatial resolution. We developed a unique transient absorption experiment to meaure the electron kinetics with femtosecond time resolution and diffraction limited space resolution. We further explored the possibility of creating artificial strain and manipulating charge/exciton accumulation for EHL formation. While our results clearly showed charge/exciton accumulation in the strained regions, formation of EHL in externally strained system is not been confirmed. 

These studies helped training 2 postdocs, 4 graduate students. 1 postdoc found a faculty position in a research one university. 1 graduate student started his own research lab in a goverment contracted lab. The other trainees are continuing their education. We have established strong collaborations with several research groups in the US. This research program also contributed to education of 3 graduate students from these groups through collaboration.
